Methodology of ASTI data collection is described here: http://www.asti.cgiar.org/methodology
No data quality reports are made by IFPRI.

Quality assurance is assured through periodic training of national-level ASTI focal points. Potential inconsistencies between new and historical datasets are always flagged by ASTI team members for in-depth follow up by national focal points.
Data quality is generally high. ASTI only covers about 80 low-and middle-income countries; it does not publish data for countries if it feels data quality is substandard.

ASTI has a wide user base, including international and regional organizations, as well as research managers and policymakers at the national level. National partners have widely used ASTI evidence to advocate for increased RD funding, the hiring/training of researchers, raising the retirement age of research staff, etc. Donors and international organizations have widely used ASTI data for priority setting and decision making. ASTI data feed into important policy documents (e.g. United Nations organizations, G8, G20, OECD, World Bank, NEPAD, etc.)
Over time, two independent impact assessments were conducted. User satisfaction of the outputs of the ASTI program was generally very high.

The dataset covers about 80 low-and middle-income countries. Datasets for Latin America and the Caribbean as well as Africa south of the Sahara are more complete and up-to-date than those for other developing regions.
Overall data accuracy is very high.

Sampling errors are minor as ASTI aims to include every single research agency operating in a country. For those few agencies that could not participate in a survey round, ASTI extrapolates data based on data the agency provided during previous survey rounds.
No information available.
Production time of dataset is approximately 12–18 months (from issuing the questionnaire to data release). This time lag is necessary for data validation, compilation, and performing data checks.
Data are released when complete. The gap between the reference year and the release date has been slightly shortened thanks to the recent introduction of more efficient software tools.

ASTI converts all its financial data into purchasing power parity (PPP) dollars. PPP exchange rates measure the relative purchasing power of currencies for a wide range of goods and services, converting current GDP prices of individual countries into a common currency. PPP conversion offers two main advantages over market exchange rates: First, PPP exchange rates are relatively stable over time, whereas market exchange rates fluctuate considerably, and second, PPP exchange rates take nontraded goods and services into account, whereas market exchange rates are affected by traded goods and capital flows only. This conversion makes the comparison of agricultural research spending across countries easier and more meaningful.

At the onset of every new national-level survey, ASTI makes an assessment of any agricultural research agencies that were established, merged, or closed down since the previous survey, before disseminating new survey forms. As a result, agency coverage is generally very complete, making ASTI data highly comparable over time (both at the country, as well as the regional/global level).

Collecting first-hand data from a complete set of agricultural research agencies is costly, as it requires substantial training of country focal points, the organization of in-country events to familiarize respondents with methodology, and travel to remote areas to ensure agency responses. The benefit of this approach is very high data quality.
ASTI team members follows up with country focal points regarding agency-level data inconsistencies or omissions.
Focal points try to address the most important data inconsistencies and omissions. For minor outstanding issues, estimations or extrapolations are made.
ASTI performs first-hand data collection on an institutional basis. It does not rely on already existing government datasets.

AE.metadata_label: Code - Type and purpose of data collection

AE.metadata_text: A first check on completeness and consistency is run as soon as the agency-level questionnaires arrive. ASTI team members follow up with country focal points on key data inconsistencies and omissions. If these are sufficiently addressed, ASTI thoroughly checks long-term timeseries data, before releasing the datasets.

Missing values are filled through Internet sources and/or personal communication with research managers working at the institutes involved. If the required information is still missing, values will be estimated based on historical data and/or averages of similar agencies operating in the country.
Long-term financial time-series data are inflation-adjusted and expressed in PPP prices to better reflect differences in price levels across countries.
